title: Llangynog Walks

images.title: John Firth / Llangynog Bridge over Afon Tanat
images.caption: Llangynog Bridge over Afon Tanat

images.title: Charles Leventon / Y Gribin, Llangynog
images.caption: Y Gribin. Slate mines and quarries above the village of Llangynog.

images.title: Penny Mayes / Craig Rhiwarth
images.caption: Craig Rhiwarth. From Llangynog which lies at the confluence of the Tanat and Eirth with three steep mountains surrounding it. Slate and granite were quarried and lead was mined here. There are still working quarries in the area.

images.title: Lane outside Llangynog by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lane outside Llangynog

images.title: Penny Mayes / Craig Rhiwarth
images.caption: Craig Rhiwarth. The picture shows a disused incline from the days of the slate quarries. Craig Rhiwarth (532m) is topped by an ancient fort.

images.title: Afon Eirth at Llangynog by John Firth, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Afon Eirth

images.title: The Tanat Valley Inn, Llangynog by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Tanat Valley Inn

description: This pretty North Welsh village sits in a fine spot at the confluence of the Rivers Tanat and Eirth. It is located at the foot of the stunning Berwyn Mountains with some fine walking trails to try. The surrounding area is often coined the Welsh Lake District with Bala Lake, Lake Vyrnwy and Llyn Celyn all nearby. This circular walk from the village climbs to Y Gribin before heading to the old quarries at Craig Rhiwarth. The scenery is very beautiful with great views of the Tanat Valley from the high points. For a more challenging walk in the area head just a few miles north east to climb to Cadair Berwyn, the highest point in the Berwyn Mountains. Near here there's also the beautiful Pistyll Rhaeadr, another of the highlights of the immediate area.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The New Inn is a nice place to enjoy rest and refreshment after your walk. The walker friendly inn serves good quality food which you can enjoy around the log fires in the cosy interior. If the weather is good then the garden area is a great place to relax. They also provide accommodation if you would like to stay in this lovely area. You can find them on Berwyn Street at a postcode of SY10 0EX for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The area is a nice place for a dog walk, though some of the hills are quite steep. The New Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the west you'll find one of the highlights of the area at the beautiful Lake Vyrnwy. There's a great cycling and walking trail around the expansive reservoir, with lots of wildlife to look out for on the way. To the north is Llandrillo where you'll find several listed buildings, views of the River Dee and the ancient Moel Ty Uchaf stone circle.

display_address: New Inn, Llangynog, Powys, Cymru / Wales, SY10 0ES, United Kingdom
